objdescid.origination: William Blakeinventor, delineator, etcher, engraver, printer

provenance.name: Fitzwilliam Museum
provenance.note: Inherited in 1827 by Catherine Blake upon her husband's death; sold March 1830 to Haviland Burke acting for John Jebb, Bishop of Limerick (with an impression of Blake's "Ezekiel" engraving, £2.2s.); bequeathed in 1833 by Burke to his chaplain, Rev. Charles Forster; by inheritance in 1871 to his son, E. M. L. Forster; by inheritance in 1880 to his sister, Laura M. Forster; by inheritance in 1924 to her nephew, the novelist E. M. Forster; given by him to King's College, Cambridge, in 1953 and transferred by the college to the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1954.

repository.addressline: Email, Department of Paintings, Drawings, and Prints: fitzmuseum-pdp@lists.cam.ac.uk
URL, Department of Paintings, Drawings, and Prints: http://www.fitzmuseum.cam.ac.uk/dept/pdp

objnote.p: This impression is in the second state of two. The plate was first etched and engraved in 1793, as the imprint indicates, and converted to this final state c. 1820-25. The final digit of the year in the imprint is poorly printed in this impression. The date is clearly "1793" in the other two known impressions of the second state (British Museum and Keynes Family Trust, Fitzwilliam Museum).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Five figures sit huddled in contracted positions in front of several tree trunks. Job, the rightmost male figure, faces forward and lifts his head to look up with raised eyes. Tears stream down his face. He is old with long hair and a beard, and he wears a gown. Both arms are slightly bent and at his sides with palms facing up and forward, fingers spread. His knees are bent upward toward his chest. Job's wife, the second figure from the right, is a gowned female who sits facing forward but turns her head to look right toward Job with raised eyes. She has long curly hair and wears sandals. Her mouth is open. Her knees are bent forward toward her chest, and she wraps both bent arms around her knees with her hands together, fingers intertwined, perhaps in a gesture of prayer. Only the head and one hand of the third figure from the right, who is male, are visible. This is probably Zophar. He faces forward and right and appears to have a mustache. One of his hands is raised in front of the left side of his face. He may rest his head on his raised hand, as his head is bent forward slightly. The second male figure from left is probably Bildad. He has short curly hair and a beard and sits facing forward and right. Most of his body is obscured by the figure sitting in front of him, though he may wear a gown. He appears to bend forward and to the right slightly. The leftmost figure is probably Eliphaz. He is gowned, or wears a shirt and cloak, and sits facing right with his knees bent beneath him and upper body bent or hunched forward. He is old and has long hair and a beard. His right arm is at his side but bent upward, perhaps to rest on his left forearm. He points to the right with his right index finger, which appears to be extended through his beard. His left arm is also bent and may rest in his lap. The ground on which the five figures sit may be covered in straw or other long grass. Behind the group of five figures, at least five tree trunks are visible. The third trunk from the left has a single bifurcated branch that extends to the left. The sky visible in the background is dark and pierced by at least one bolt of lightning between the third and fourth trunks from the right. There may be other, smaller bolts between the first tree on the left and the second and between the second and third tree from the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Five figures sit huddled in contracted positions in front of several tree trunks. Job, the rightmost figure, faces forward and lifts his head to look up with raised eyes. Tears stream down his face. He is old with long hair and a beard, and he wears a gown. Both arms are slightly bent and at his sides with palms facing up and forward, fingers spread. His knees are bent upward toward his chest. This figure is likely Job.

Five figures sit huddled in contracted positions in front of several tree trunks. Job's wife, the second figure from the right, is a gowned female figure who sits facing forward but turns her head to look right toward her companion with raised eyes. She has long curly hair and wears sandals. Her mouth is open. Her knees are bent forward toward her chest, and she wraps both bent arms around her knees with her hands together, fingers intertwined, perhaps in a gesture of prayer.

Five figures sit huddled in contracted positions in front of several tree trunks. Only the head and one hand of the third figure from the right, who is male, are visible. He faces forward and right and appears to have a mustache. One of his hands is raised in front of the left side of his face. He may rest his head on his raised hand, as his head is bent forward slightly with eyes raised. This is probably Zophar, given the probable identification of this figure in Blake's later series of Job designs.

Five figures sit huddled in contracted positions in front of several tree trunks. The second male figure from left, who has short curly hair and a beard, sits facing forward and right. Most of his body is obscured by the figure sitting in front of him, though he may wear a gown. He appears to bend forward and to the right slightly, perhaps to look toward the figure at far right. This is probably Bildad, given the probable identification of this figure in Blake's later series of Job designs.

Five figures sit huddled in contracted positions in front of several tree trunks. The leftmost figure kneels facing right with his knees bent beneath him and upper body bent or hunched forward. He wears a gown or shirt and cloak. He is old and has long hair and a beard. His right arm is at his side but bent upward, perhaps to rest on his left forearm. He points to the right with his right index finger, which appears to be extended through his beard. His left arm is also bent and may rest in his lap. This is probably Eliphaz, given the probable identification of this figure in Blake's later series of Job designs.
The ground on which the five figures sit may be covered in straw or other long grass.

component.characteristic: Behind the group of five figures, at least five tree trunks are visible. The third trunk from the left has a single bifurcated branch that extends at left, and the rightmost tree may have moss or vines visible on its trunk—or at least very reticulated bark.

component.illusobjdesc: The sky visible in the background is dark and pierced by at least one bolt of lightning between the third and fourth trunks from the right. There may be other, smaller bolts between the first tree on the left and the second and between the second and third tree from the right.

l.hi: Painted and Engraved by William Blake
What is Man That thou shouldest Try him Every Moment? Job VII C 17 & 18 V
Published 18 August 1793 by W Blake No 13 Hercules Buildings Lambeth
